context: DongKoh
Carols should be jingly, cats should be fat and new experiences should be familiar.

Hi, I’m Dong-yoon Koh :) 

I’ve just completed my masters at the Industrial Design department of KAIST. As a member of the CIXD lab and under the tutelage of Prof. Lim, I’ve studied and experimented with how design research methodologies can be applied in the design of emerging technologies such as conversational interfaces and recommender systems.
kw:
My interest lies in the design of new experiences that emerging technologies can potentially call forth. While I fully awknowledge the common notion that designers should be able to envision efficient, meaningful, and even magical experiences, I place my foremost design priority in creating familiar experiences. Just as early digital applications had leveraged skeuomorphism, I believe that the design of new experiences should be able to make reference to familiar experiences to place the emerging technology in the hand of the general users. 

The design and development of emerging technology should be able to complement each other.Our cognition of human behaviors are not always spot on and seldom represent the entirety, and as such, the exploration and understanding of human behavior that design research can provide should both guide and be guided by the outcomes of technological advances. Based on this belief and as a budding designer, I hope to position myself up close to where new things are happening.

Deployed a website in anticipation of (to be more frank, in fear of) starting my military service somewhere deep in the mountainous frontier. Little did I now that google was blocked at the military base.

title: Kim, H., { Koh, D. }, Lee, G., Park, J., and Lim, Y., "Designing Personalities of Conversational Agents," Extended Abstracts of CHI 2019, ACM Press, (Glasgow, Scotland, UK, May 4-9), Paper LBW1321.
context: Recent years have seen numerous attempts to imbue conversational agents with marked identities by crafting their personalities. However, the question remains as to how such personalities can be systematically designed. To address this problem, this paper proposes a conceptual framework for designing and communicating agent personalities. We conducted two design workshops with 12 designers, discovering three dimensions of an agent personality and three channels to express it. The study results revealed that an agent personality can be crafted by designing common traits shared within a service domain, distinctive traits added for a unique identity, and neutral traits left intentionally undecided or user-driven. Also, such a personality can be expressed through how an agent performs services, what contents it provides, and how it speaks and appears to be. Our results suggest a renewed view of the dimensions of conversational agent personalities.
kw: Conversational Agent; Personality; Voice User interface; Interaction Design;

title: Kim, H., { Koh, D. }, Lee, G., Park, J., and Lim, Y., "Developing a Design Guide for Consistent Manifestation of Conversational Agent Personalities," Proceedings of IASDR 2019, (Manchester, UK, September 2-5).
context: Consistency in a personality of a conversational agent plays a crucial role in forming user expectations towards interaction and determining the quality of user experience. For an agent personality to be manifested consistently, designers should be able to communicate the personality they designed clearly and concretely to multiple dialogue designers so that the same understanding of the intended personality is shared among them. This paper proposes a design guide to support such communication to ensure consistent manifestation of an agent personality throughout conversations crafted by multiple designers. In reference to a conversational agent personality framework and the speech act theory, we developed the guide that supports designers to grasp how an agent personality was designed as well as how to manifest it in various conversational situations. While we evaluated the guide in a Wizard-of-Oz-based user study, we also explored what should be considered in order for designers to maintain consistency of manifested personality in conversational interactions. The findings related to users’ perception of a consistent agent personality were threefold: users perceived roles and functions of an agent as its personality; cross-situational consistency in style of providing services and contents mattered; and users were tolerant for inconsistency in verbal and physical modalities. We conclude the paper with discussion on potential benefits of the guide.
kw: Agent personality; Consistency; Conversational agent; Design guide

title: { Koh, D. }, Kim, J., Yun, D., and Lim, Y., "PlayMaker: A Participatory Design Method for Creating Entertainment Application Concepts Using Activity Data," Asian CHI Symposium at CHI 2019, (Glasgow, UK, May 5).
context: The public’s ever-growing interest in health has led the well-being industry to explosive growth over the years. This propelled activity trackers as one of the trendiest items among the current day wearable devices. Seeking new opportunities for effective data utilization, we present a participatory design method that explores the fusion of activity data with entertainment application. In this method we spur participants to design by mix-and-matching activity tracker data attributes to existing entertainment application features to produce new concepts.The public’s ever-growing interest in health has led the well-being industry to explosive growth over the years. In this method we spur participants to design by mix-and-matching activity tracker data attributes to existing entertainment application features to produce new concepts.
kw: Design workshop; Concept development; Activity tracker; Entertainment
